questions.text: How does the graft get nutrition on day 3?
questions.solution:
Correct option B -Inosculation

         On day 3 ,  inosculation starts in which graft and host vessels form anastomosis.This means capillary buds from the recipient bed begin to connect with the graft’s vessels, allowing some blood flow and nutrient delivery.

Day Nutritional Mechanism
0–2 Plasmatic imbibition (diffusion)
~3 Inosculation (capillary connections form)
4–7 Neovascularization (new vessels grow in)

 

Incorrect Options:

Option  A- Imbibition:Occurs during the first 24–48 hours after graft placement.The graft absorbs nutrients, oxygen, and plasma passively by diffusion from the vascular bed of the recipient site..

 

Option C - Neovascularization: Neovascularization involves the growth of new blood vessels into the graft from the host tissue. This process generally begins more than 5 days after the graft is placed and is crucial for sustaining the graft over the long term by providing a more robust blood supply.

questions.text: A 30 year old female was brought to EMR after fire on examination of lower limb full-thickness burns and deep partial-thickness burns were present involving it Circumferentially, procedure was performed as given below, identify the procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Escharotomy

Explanation: The appropriatet answer is escharotomy because circumferential full-thickness burns produce a tough, leathery, non-elastic eschar. This can restrict circulation and ventilation (if on chest) due to swelling beneath the eschar.

  • Escharotomy is an emergency procedure where the eschar is incised longitudinally to relieve pressure, restore distal circulation, and prevent compartment syndrome.
  • It is performed along the medial and lateral aspects of the limb, avoiding neurovascular bundles.

Debridement (Option B): Removal of necrotic tissue, usually done during wound care, not the immediate emergency procedure for circumferential burns with vascular compromise.

Excised to healthy tissue fat/fascia (Option C): Refers to tangential or fascial excision in burn surgery, typically performed in planned operative settings, not as an emergency decompression.

Early skin grafting (Option D): Performed after excision of burn tissue to cover wounds and promote healing; not indicated as the first step in this emergency.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male child was brought to the EMR 6 hours after a burn and was having 22% BSA burns. On examination, cool extremities, BP - 92/50mmHg, PR - 56 BPM. Urine output since burn episode: 30ml. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Give a bolus of 10 ml/kg/hr

Explanation:

  • The child has burn shock — evidenced by hypotension, bradycardia (late sign in children), cool extremities, and low urine output. In pediatric burns, >15% BSA requires urgent IV fluid resuscitation to prevent progression to multi-organ failure.
  • This patient is 6 hours post-burn, meaning there is already an ongoing deficit that must be corrected promptly. Therefore, an initial bolus: 10 ml/kg of Ringer’s lactate is recommended to restore circulation before calculated maintenance fluids.
  • Colloids are not given early because, during the first 24 hours, capillary permeability is markedly increased → colloids leak into the interstitium → worsen edema. Colloids (e.g., albumin) are generally started after 24 hours.

Burn Fluid Resuscitation:

Formula

Calculation

Notes

Parkland formula

4 ml × body weight (kg) × %BSA burned

Use Ringer’s lactate; give ½ in first 8 hrs (from time of burn), remainder in next 16 hrs

Children

Same as adults, but add maintenance fluids (Holliday–Segar method)

Monitor urine output (goal: 1 ml/kg/hr)

Evans formula

Crystalloids + colloids after 24 hrs

Rarely used now

Brooke formula

2 ml × kg × %BSA + maintenance

Modified approach to reduce over-resuscitation

Nutrition in Burns:

  • Hypermetabolic state → ↑ protein and calorie requirement.
  • Early enteral feeding within 24 hrs reduces infections & maintains gut integrity.
  • Protein: 1.5–2 g/kg/day (children may need up to 3 g/kg/day).
  • Calories: 1.5–2 times basal requirement (can use Curreri formula: 25 kcal × kg + 40 kcal × %BSA burned).
  • Supplement vitamins A, C, and zinc to promote healing.

Colloids in Burns:

  • Avoid in the first 24 hrs due to increased vascular permeability.
  • After 24 hrs, it may be used to maintain plasma oncotic pressure and reduce total crystalloid requirement.
  • Common colloids: albumin, plasma protein fraction.

Give colloid bolus (Option B) – Not indicated in the first 24 hrs; will leak into tissues and worsen edema.

Surgical intervention (Option C) – Definitive management is delayed until the patient is hemodynamically stable.

Give bolus at 30 ml/kg/hr (Option D) – Unsafe; may cause fluid overload, pulmonary edema, and abdominal compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A patient underwent split-thickness skin grafting for a burn injury on the arm. On post-operative day 6, he develops stiffness of the arm during physiotherapy. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Passive extension of the joint under direct visualization of the graft
Remove the graft and regraft the area

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Passive extension of the joint under direct visualization of the graft

Explanation: By post-operative day 6, the split-thickness skin graft is in the fibrovascular ingrowth and early maturation phase. If stiffness develops during physiotherapy, the safest approach is to perform passive extension under direct visualization to ensure that the graft is not disrupted.

  • This allows assessment of graft integrity and prevention of shearing forces that could cause partial or total graft loss.

Surgical excision of contracture (Option A): Contracture release is indicated in long-standing, mature scars, not within the first week after grafting.

Continue physiotherapy without intervention (Option C): Risk of damaging the graft if stiffness is due to early adhesion or improper graft placement; should first ensure graft safety.

Remove the graft and regraft the area (Option D): Not necessary unless the graft has failed; stiffness alone at day 6 is not an indication for regrafting.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct regarding nerve grafts:


	Nerve graft is used for peripheral nerves
	It is used for surgical repair of facial nerve palsy
	Most common nerve grafts are saphenous nerve and anterior interosseous nerve
	Nerve graft can be reconstructed only with fibrin glue
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 2

Explanation:

  • Nerve grafts are used to reconstruct peripheral nerves (including the brachial plexus) and in the surgical management of facial palsy (by utilising a cross-facial nerve graft) and corneal paraesthesia. Common donor nerves include the sural nerve, medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve and the sensory branch of the posterior interosseous nerve (ideal for digital nerve grafts). Whereas vessels are ‘anastomosed’, nerves are ‘coapted’ – typically using epineurial sutures with or without fibrin glue in a tension-free manner.

questions.text: The following approach is used in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Correcting Dog ear

Explanation:

  • Dog's ear refers to a puckered or folded deformity at the end of a wound or incision, often occurring after elliptical excisions or closures under tension.
  • The approach used to correct a dog's ear involves triangular excision and re-approximation to flatten the skin and ensure a smooth closure.

Keloid excision (Option A) - Typically involves wider excision and adjunct therapies (e.g., steroids, radiation).

Abscess Drainage (Option B) - Requires incision and drainage, not dog-ear correction.

Split thickness skin graft (Option D) - Skin grafts are used to achieve wound closure in situations where the skin defects are too large for primary closure and healing by secondary intention may be inappropriate or lead to an unreasonable delay in complete healing such as burns.

questions.text: Identify the procedure given below in the image?

choices.text: Transposition flap is used for scar revision

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Transposition flap used for scar revision

Explanation:

  • The given image is that of Z-plasty, a surgical technique used to realign scars with natural skin folds or relaxed tension lines and to lengthen contracted scars.
  • It involves creating two triangular flaps of equal size, which are then transposed to redirect and release the scar.
  • Z-plasty is a type of random flap used for grafting purposes, and the other type of random flap is V-Y plasty.

Split-thickness skin grafting (Option B) is a surgical technique used to repair skin defects by transferring a thin layer of skin from a donor site to the recipient site. The graft includes the epidermis and a variable thickness of the underlying dermis. It is not a random flap technique.

Repositioning flap without transposition (Option C) involves moving a flap directly forward to cover a defect, without rotating or pivoting it across adjacent tissue, but Z-plasty requires transposition.

Tissue transplantation (Option D) is a procedure that involves replacing damaged or missing tissues or organs with healthy ones from a donor. The types of grafts used can be an Autograft, Allograft, Xenograft or Isograft.

questions.text: What is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B- Sebaceous cyst.

Sebaceous cysts are common benign cystic lesions that arise from the sebaceous glands in the skin. They often appear as slow-growing, painless swellings beneath the skin. Sebaceous cysts contain a thick, cheesy material called sebum and can occur in various areas of the body, including the face, neck, scalp, or trunk. Black-colored punctum is seen in cysts except cysts present in the scalp and scrotum, as shown in the image in the question.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A-Dermoid cyst:

  • A dermoid cyst is a type of benign cystic lesion that typically contains a variety of different types of tissues, such as hair, skin, and sometimes even teeth.
  • These cysts are usually present since birth and can occur in various parts of the body.

Option C- Meningioma:

  • Meningiomas are typically slow-growing tumors that arise from the meninges, the protective layers surrounding the brain and spinal cord. They are usually found within the cranial cavity and are less commonly located near the postauricular area. Meningiomas are not typically associated with the specific appearance of the image provided.

Option D- Post auricular fistula:

  • A postauricular fistula is a small abnormal tract or passage that connects the skin behind the ear to the underlying structures. It can present as a small opening with drainage or discharge. The image provided does not depict a postauricular fistula, as it shows a cystic lesion rather than a fistulous opening.

questions.text: What is the preferred management of the condition in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Surgical excision

Explanation:

  • The given image suggests an Angular dermoid cyst ,and the preferred management for this is surgical excision, as it completely removes the cyst and prevents recurrence.

Angular Dermoid

Presentation

It commonly occurs as a smooth, non-tender, soft swelling at the fronto-zygomatic suture.

Location

They are most often located near the lateral canthus, which is the outer corner of the eye where the upper and lower eyelids meet. They may also occur near suture lines of the skull.

Symptoms

They are usually asymptomatic unless they become large enough to cause pressure effects on adjacent structures or become infected.

Diagnosis

Ultrasound or CT scans may be used to evaluate the extent of the cyst, especially if deep or orbital involvement is suspected.

Management

(Option A)

Surgical Excision: Complete surgical excision is the treatment of choice, especially if the cyst is causing cosmetic concerns or other symptoms.

  • Careful dissection is required to ensure the cyst is fully removed and avoid recurrence.
  • If left untreated, angular dermoids sometimes undergo resorption or indentation of the underlying base. CT is done to rule out dural attachments.

Radiotherapy (Option B) is not a standard treatment for dermoid cysts. It is typically used for malignant tumours or conditions such as cancer and is not indicated for benign lesions like dermoid cysts.

Antibiotics (Option C) are used for bacterial infections. They are not the treatment of choice for an uncomplicated dermoid cyst as it is non-infectious. They are only needed if the cyst becomes infected.

Intralesional steroids (Option D) are typically used for conditions like keloids or hypertrophic scars and are not effective in treating dermoid cysts. The goal for dermoid cysts is to remove the cyst hence, surgical excision is the appropriate approach.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for the lesion developed by a patient after 6 months of undergoing heart surgery, as depicted below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Keloid scar

Explanation:

  • The most probable diagnosis based on the image and the lesion that developed 6 months after heart surgery is a keloid scar.
  • It is characterized by abnormal and excessive growth of scar tissue that grows beyond the boundaries of the original wound and does not regress.
  • It typically appears firm, raised, and extends beyond the margins of the initial injury.
  • Keloid formation seems to be an individual predisposition, and it is more common in African Americans.
  • Sternum is the most common site for Keloid formation.
  • Treatment can be done by intralesional injection of steroids like Triamcinolone.

Hypertrophic scars (Option A) are also raised, they typically remain within the boundaries of the original injury. They may regress over time and are less likely to recur after treatment compared to keloids.

Atrophic scars (Option B) are pale, flat, and depressed scars that appear sunken or as indentations in the skin due to loss of tissue or collagen.

Contracture (Option D) occurs when scar tissue forms and tightens, leading to restricted movement of nearby joints or tissues. They typically occur in case of burns or deep wounds. Contractures may result in deformity and functional impairment.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented with a burn injury. He is covered with burns on his head & neck, both upper limbs, front and back of the chest. Calculate the percentage of burns.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 45%

Explanation:

  • The correct answer in the given condition is 45% based on the rule of 9.
  • To calculate the percentage of burns, we can use the Rule of Nines, a system commonly used to estimate the body surface area (BSA) affected by burns.
  • Since the patient in the scenario is an adult,
    • Burned area% = Head & neck (9%) + Both upper limbs (18%) + Front & back of the chest (18%) = 45%

Rule of Nines

 

Adults

Children

Infants

Head & neck

9%

18%

20%

Front of chest & abdominal wall

9 x 2 = 18%

18%

10 x 2 = 20%

Back of chest & abdominal wall

9 x 2 = 18%

18%

10 x 2 = 20%

Lower limb

18 x 2 = 36%

13.5 x 2 = 27%

10 x 2 = 20%

Upper limb

9 x 2 = 18%

18%

10 x 2 = 20%

Perineum

1%

1%

questions.text: A 65-year-old man who has the following lesion over the face. He complains of bleeding while itching. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Basal cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Basal cell carcinoma, a slow-growing malignant tumor, invades locally and primarily affects the pilosebaceous skin. It's mainly categorised into localized and generalized forms, with nodular and nodulocystic variants comprising 90% of cases.
  • Typically, it appears as a pink, pearly papule with telangiectasias, rolled borders, and central crusty ulcerations.

 

Dermatofibrosarcoma (Option A) It is a soft tissue sarcoma that presents as a reddish-brown plaque that does not have rolled borders as seen in the image.

Marjolin’s ulcer (Option B) Marjolin’s ulcer can develop into squamous cell carcinoma. It occurs on a previously long-standing scar. The image shown is not marjolin’s ulcer.

Nevus (Option D) It is a benign skin growth that occurs due to the accumulation of melanocytes. The image shown is not a nevus.

questions.text: What type of dressing is used to cover this post burn wound?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Split thickness skin graft:

  • A split-thickness skin graft (STSG) involves transplanting the top layers of skin (epidermis and part of the dermis) from a donor site to cover a post-burn wound. After the graft is applied, dressings are used to secure it, promote adherence, and protect the wound. The graft itself is the primary coverage for the wound.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Full Thickness Skin Graft: This option refers to a different type of graft where both the epidermis and the entire dermis are transplanted. Full-thickness grafts are used for smaller wounds requiring greater durability and better cosmetic outcomes. However, they are not typically used for extensive post-burn wound coverage.

Option C - VAC Dressing: Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) dressing is used to promote healing in complex wounds by applying negative pressure. It’s often used for deep or chronic wounds but is not the primary method for covering a fresh skin graft.

Option D - Normal Sumag Dressing: While normal dressings may be used as secondary coverage to protect the graft site, they are not the primary method for securing a grafted area.

questions.text: Estimate the extent of injury for a patient with burns involving the chest, abdomen, right upper limb, and the whole of the right thigh.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 36%

Explanation:

According to Wallace's rule of 9

  • Chest and abdomen = 18% (9% on each side)
  • Right upper limb = 9%
  • Right thigh = 9%
  • (Total=18+9+9=36)

According to the Wallace rule of 9, the area burned is calculated as:

 

Adults

Children

Infants

Head & neck

9%

18%

20%

Front of chest & abdominal wall

9 x 2 = 18%

18%

10 x 2 = 20%

Back of chest & abdominal wall

9 x 2 = 18%

18%

10 x 2 = 20%

Lower limb

18 x 2 = 36%

13.5 x 2 = 27%

10 x 2 = 20%

Upper limb

9 x 2 = 18%

18%

10 x 2 = 20%

Perineum

1%

1%

questions.text: A 56-year-old female was treated for a burn wound in the lower limb 5 years ago. Now she has developed an ulcer in the burn scar as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Marjolin’s ulcer:

  • Marjolin's ulcer is a type of skin cancer that arises from chronic non-healing wounds, scars, or ulcers, usually after a prolonged period of time (years).
  • It is most commonly associated with burn wounds.
  • The appearance of a chronic ulcer following a burn injury is a classic indication of Marjolin's ulcer.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Venous ulcer:

  • Venous ulcers typically occur due to chronic venous insufficiency.
  • They usually appear around the ankles and lower legs and are characterized by shallow, irregularly shaped ulcers with a red or yellowish base.
  • They are often associated with edema, varicose veins, and skin discoloration.

Option C - Arterial ulcer:

  • Arterial ulcers are a result of inadequate blood supply to the tissue, usually due to underlying arterial disease such as peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
  • These ulcers often occur on the feet, toes, or lower legs and are characterized by a "punched out" appearance with well-defined edges.
  • The base may appear pale or necrotic.

Option D - Cellulitis:

  • Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection that typically presents as redness, swelling, warmth, and pain at the affected site.
  • While cellulitis can occur at sites of wounds or breaks in the skin, it does not typically present as a chronic ulcer.

questions.text: What type of graft is used when a patient undergoes skin grafting following a road traffic accident in which the graft is harvested from the patient's own body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Autograft

Explanation:

  • The graft harvested from the patient's own body is called an autograft.

Types of Grafts

 

Graft Type

Source

Advantages

Disadvantages

Autograft

(Option A)

Tissue from one site to another on the same individual

No risk of immune rejection; high success rate

Requires a donor site, additional morbidity

Allograft

(Option C ruled out)

Tissue from another individual of the same species

Availability of larger tissue amounts

Risk of immune rejection; needs immunosuppression

Xenograft

(Option B ruled out)

Tissue from a different species (e.g., pig to human)

Readily available; used as temporary grafts

High risk of immune rejection; often temporary

Isograft

(Option D ruled out)

Tissue between genetically identical individuals

No risk of immune rejection due to genetic identity

Limited availability; specific to identical twins
  • Concordant Xenograft:
    • Xenograft between closely related species.
    • Compatibility: Better immune compatibility; lower risk of hyperacute rejection.
    • Example: Primate to human (e.g., baboon to human).
  • Discordant Xenograft:
    • Xenograft between distantly related species.
    • Compatibility: Poor immune compatibility; high risk of hyperacute rejection.
    • Example: Pig to human.

questions.text: In the case of a woman who has suffered third and fourth degree burns on her back, what would be the appropriate sequence of steps in her treatment?
questions.solution:
• Third-degree burns affect the full thickness of the skin and can cause damage to underlying tissue, while fourth-degree burns extend into the muscle, bone, or internal organs. Both types of burns require prompt and aggressive treatment to prevent complications such as infection, hypovolemia, and shock.
  • The most appropriate order of sequence in the management of a woman who has sustained third and fourth-degree burns on her back is as follows:
  • Resuscitation: The first step in the management of severe burns is resuscitation. This involves assessing and stabilizing the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation. Intravenous fluids and electrolytes are administered to prevent hypovolemia and maintain hemodynamic stability.
  • Debridement: Once the patient is stabilized, the next step is debridement. Debridement involves removing all necrotic tissue and debris from the wound to prevent infection and promote healing. Surgical or non-surgical methods can do debridement.
  • Allograft or autograft: After debridement, the wound is covered with either an allograft or autograft. Allografts are skin grafts taken from another person, while autografts are skin grafts taken from the patient's own body. Both types of grafts can provide temporary coverage to the wound and promote wound healing.
  • Therefore, the correct option would be Resuscitation – Debridement – Allograft or Autograft.

Incorrect Choices: 

  • Option a. Resuscitation – reconstruction – debridement is incorrect because Ressuscitation – Debridement – Allograft or Autograft is the correct sequence.
  • Option c: Debridement – resuscitation – autograft is incorrect because Resuscitation – Debridement – Allograft or Autograft is the correct sequence.
  • Option d: Reconstruction is not an appropriate step in the initial management of third and fourth-degree burns, as the focus should be on stabilizing the patient and preventing complications. Reconstruction is typically done later in the treatment process once the wound has healed. Thus, Resuscitation – Debridement – Allograft or Autograft is the correct sequence.

questions.text: What is the preferred management of angular dermoid cyst?

choices.text: Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Surgical excision

Explanation :

  • Angular dermoid is a type of dermoid cyst that commonly occurs as a smooth, non-tender, soft swelling at the fronto-zygomatic suture.
  • The formation of an angular dermoid is due to the sequestration of ectodermal tissue during embryonic development, which gives rise to a cyst containing dermal elements like hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and sweat glands.
  • Angular dermoids are most often located near the lateral canthus, which is the outer corner of the eye where the upper and lower eyelids meet. They may also occur near suture lines of the skull.
  • They are usually asymptomatic unless they become large enough to cause pressure effects on adjacent structures or become infected.
  • Diagnosis and Treatment:
    • Imaging: Ultrasound or CT scans may be used to evaluate the extent of the cyst, especially if deep or orbital involvement is suspected.
    • Surgical Excision: Complete surgical excision is the treatment of choice, especially if the cyst is causing cosmetic concerns or other symptoms. Careful dissection is required to ensure that the cyst is fully removed and to avoid recurrence.
    • If left untreated, angular dermoids sometimes undergo resorption or indentation of the underlying base. CT is done to rule out dural attachments.

Wait and watch (Option B) This is not recommended for angular dermoids, as they can grow or become infected. Surgical excision is the definitive treatment.

Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin (Option C) A wide excision is unnecessary. Angular dermoids are benign, so simple surgical excision without wide margins is sufficient.

Laser ablation (Option D) is inappropriate for treating angular dermoids. Surgical excision ensures complete removal of the cyst, preventing recurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Marjolin’s ulcer is not true?

choices.text: It is seen in sites of chronic wounds or scars
It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma
It is radioresistant due to avascularity

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) It rapidly progresses to malignancy

Explanation:

  • A marjolin’s ulcer usually occurs on long-standing chronic wound scars. It presents as a non-healing ulcer with elevated margins that grow rapidly.
  • In some cases, it can become malignant and progress to squamous cell carcinoma. It is usually treated by surgical excision using Mohs surgery, where the lesion, along with a 1-2 cm margin is removed.

 

It is seen in the site of chronic wounds or scars (Option A). This statement regarding Marjolin’s ulcer is true.

It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma (Option C) It has a greater chance of progressing to squamous cell carcinoma rather than basal cell carcinoma.

It is radioresistant due to avascularity (Option D). This statement is also true as Marjolin’s ulcer has less vascularity and can be radioresistant.

questions.text: Pressure greater than __ mm of Hg causes pressure sores.:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 33

Explanation:

  • Pressure sores (also called decubitus ulcers or pressure ulcers) occur due to prolonged pressure on the skin, leading to ischemia and tissue necrosis.
  • The critical pressure threshold that exceeds capillary perfusion pressure and causes ischemia is greater than 33 mmHg.
  • Normal capillary pressure is around 25–32 mmHg, so pressure exceeding 33 mmHg leads to inadequate blood supply and tissue damage.

45 mmHg, 54 mmHg, 67 mmHg (Option B, C and D)

  • While higher pressures can accelerate tissue necrosis, ischemia begins at pressures just above 33 mmHg.
  • Higher pressures are often seen in bony prominences (e.g., sacrum, heels), but even lower sustained pressure over time can lead to ulcers.

questions.text: A patient who underwent surgery for a lipoma 5 weeks ago now presents with a scar at the incision site that is limited to the original wound boundaries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Hypertrophic scar

Explanation:

Comparison of Hypertrophic Scar, Keloid, Exuberant Granulation, and Granulation Tissue

Feature

Hypertrophic Scar

Keloid

Exuberant Granulation ("Proud Flesh")

Granulation Tissue

Definition

Excess collagen deposition leading to a raised scar within wound boundaries.

(Option D ruled out )

Excess collagen deposition extending beyond the wound. (Option A ruled out )

Overgrowth of granulation tissue above skin level. (Option B ruled out )

Early vascularized tissue forming during wound healing. (Option C)

Wound Boundaries

Confined to the original wound.

Extends beyond the wound margins.

Protrudes beyond the skin level.

Confined to wound, but not raised.

Onset

Weeks after injury.

Months after injury.

Early post-injury phase.

Forms within days of injury.

Resolution

May regress over time.

Persists and grows continuously.

Requires treatment (cauterization or excision).

Normal component of healing.

Common Locations

Areas of high tension (joints, chest, back).

Earlobes, shoulders, chest, upper arms.

Open wounds, surgical sites.

Any healing wound.

Histology

Collagen organized parallel to skin surface.

Disorganized, excessive collagen deposition.

Excess granulation tissue, rich in capillaries.

Fibroblasts, capillaries, and inflammatory cells.

Treatment

Pressure therapy, steroids, laser therapy (if symptomatic).

Intralesional steroids, cryotherapy, excision (high recurrence).

Silver nitrate cautery, surgical trimming.

No treatment needed (normal part of healing).

questions.text: Most common subtype of Rodent ulcer is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Nodular:

  • The most common subtype of Rodent ulcer is Nodular.

  • Rodent ulcer, also known as basal cell carcinoma (BCC), is a common type of skin cancer that typically occurs on areas of the skin exposed to the sun, such as the face, neck, and hands. BCC is the most common form of skin cancer and is characterized by slow-growing, locally invasive tumors.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Superficial BCC: This subtype is characterized by a red, scaly patch or plaque on the skin. It tends to grow slowly and can be mistaken for eczema or a patch of psoriasis.

Option B - Cystic BCC: This subtype appears as a translucent or pearly nodule with central cystic areas. It may have a smooth, shiny surface and can resemble a benign cyst.

Option D - Pigmented BCC: Is rare variant

questions.text: Cellulitis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Suprative & Invasive:

  • Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection characterized by inflammation of the skin and underlying tissues. 

  • Cellulitis is considered suppurative because it often involves the formation of pus, which consists of dead white blood cells, bacteria, and tissue debris. It is invasive because the bacterial infection penetrates and spreads through the deeper layers of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, causing inflammation and damage beyond the surface layer. This invasion can lead to significant tissue destruction and systemic complications if not promptly treated with antibiotics and proper wound care.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nonsuppurative & Noninvasive: Stating cellulitis as nonsuppurative and noninvasive, is incorrect. Cellulitis is typically associated with the presence of pus (suppuration) due to bacterial infection, and it can involve deeper layers of the skin and tissues (invasive).

Option B - Nonsuppurative & invasive: Stating cellulitis as nonsuppurative and invasive, is also incorrect. While cellulitis can be invasive, it is commonly associated with the presence of pus (suppuration) as bacteria invade and cause an inflammatory response in the affected area.

Option C - Suprative & Noninvasive: Stating cellulitis as suppurative and noninvasive, is incorrect as well. Cellulitis often involves the production of pus (suppuration) due to bacterial infection, and it can extend into deeper tissues (invasive).

questions.text: A lady with 50% TBSA burn + involvement of dermis & subcutaneous tissue came to the emergency department. Which degree burn is this:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 3rd degree:

  • A third-degree burn, also known as a full-thickness burn, involves the complete destruction of the epidermis and dermis and extends into the subcutaneous tissue. It typically appears as a white or charred area and is often painless due to the destruction of nerve endings. In the given scenario, with 50% total body surface area (TBSA) involvement and the inclusion of dermis and subcutaneous tissue, it is classified as a third-degree burn.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1st degree: A first-degree burn, also known as a superficial burn, only affects the outermost layer of the skin, the epidermis.

Option B - 2nd degree superficial: A 2nd-degree superficial burn, also called a partial-thickness burn, involves both the epidermis and a portion of the underlying dermis.

Option C - 2nd degree deep: A 2nd-degree deep burn, also a partial-thickness burn, affects the epidermis and extends deeper into the dermis, involving the deeper layers of the skin. It often presents with redness, pain, blistering, and severe swelling.

questions.text: What does the inclusion of a split-thickness skin graft in wound closure on the thigh entail?

choices.text: Epidermis and variable part of the dermis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Epidermis and variable part of the dermis: 

  • STSG (split-thickness skin graft) involves taking a graft that includes the epidermis and a variable portion of the dermis.
  • This type of graft allows for a larger area of skin to be harvested compared to full-thickness grafts, which take the entire thickness of the skin.
  • Common donor sites for STSG include the inner aspect of the thigh, upper arm, flexor aspect of the forearm, and abdominal wall.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C and D: Refer to the explanation of correct option.

questions.text: What is the specific instrument utilized for extracting the graft from the healthy region during split thickness skin grafting?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Humby knife:

  • The Humby knife, also known as a dermatome knife, is a specialized instrument used for skin grafting. It is specifically designed to harvest thin slices of skin, making it suitable for split-thickness skin grafting procedures. The Humby knife allows controlled removal of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis from the donor site.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dermatome: A dermatome is the correct instrument used for harvesting split-thickness skin grafts. It is a surgical instrument specifically designed for this purpose. The dermatome allows controlled and precise removal of the epidermis and a variable thickness of the dermis from the healthy donor area. The harvested graft is then transferred to the recipient site, where it is secured and allowed to heal.

Option B - Silver's knife: Silver's knife, also known as a razor or scalpel, is a general surgical instrument used for various purposes, including making incisions and excisions. While a scalpel may be used during certain steps of the split-thickness skin grafting procedure, it is not the primary instrument for graft harvesting.

Option C - Catlin amputating knife: Catlin amputating knife is a type of surgical instrument used for amputations or limb removal. It is not typically used for harvesting split-thickness skin grafts, as its design and purpose are different.

questions.text: ABCDE rule applies for:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Malignant melanoma:

  • ABCDE rule for malignant melanoma:
    • A - Asymmetry
    • B - Border irregularity
    • C - Color variation
    • D - Diameter (> 6mm)
    • E - Evolution (changes over time)

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C & D are incorrect. Refer to explanation of correct option.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a known case of the varicose veins in the lower limbs has developed itching and ulceration around the ankle and calf region for a few days. Venous ulcers of the lower limb usually develop in the area of the calf and ankle. Which ulcer is likely to develop in a long-standing chronic venous ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Marjolin's ulcer:

  • Marjolin's ulcer refers to a malignant transformation (squamous cell carcinoma) that can occur in a long-standing chronic wound or scar.

  • In the case of a long-standing chronic venous ulcer, there is a risk of developing Marjolin's ulcer over time.

  • Venous ulcers typically occur in the lower limbs, particularly in the calf and ankle region, due to chronic venous insufficiency.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Aphthous ulcer: Aphthous ulcers, also known as canker sores, are shallow and painful ulcers that occur in the oral cavity, not in the lower limbs.

Option C - Pressure sores: Pressure sores, also known as bedsores or decubitus ulcers, develop over bony prominences due to prolonged pressure and lack of blood flow. They are not specific to the calf and ankle region.

Option D - Necrotizing fasciitis: Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe bacterial infection that affects the deeper layers of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It is not specific to the calf and ankle region and is not directly associated with long-standing venous ulcers

questions.text: Comment on the diagnosis of this 60 years of man:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - SCC of lip:

  • The diagnosis for this 60-year-old man is SCC (Squamous Cell Carcinoma) of the lip, as shown in the image.

  • Based on the image showing SCC of the lip, it is evident that the patient has a malignant tumor involving the lip. Squamous cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that commonly occurs in sun-exposed areas, including the lips. It typically presents as a non-healing ulcer or a raised, crusted lesion with irregular borders.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Basal cell carcinoma: Basal cell carcinoma is another common type of skin cancer, but it typically presents with different clinical features and is less likely to be associated with lip involvement.

Option B - Plunging Ranula: Plunging ranula refers to a cystic lesion that occurs in the floor of the mouth and is not related to lip carcinoma.

Option C - Epulis: Epulis refers to a benign tumor or overgrowth of tissue, which is different from the malignant nature of the lesion seen in the image.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true with regards to a keloid scar?

choices.text: The extant does not cross the wound margins
Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence
Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity
A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors:

  • Keloids result from an overactive healing response to an injury.

  • A keloid scar develops from heightened levels of growth factors, resulting in excessive tissue formation beyond the boundaries of the original wound, often leading to raised, thickened scar tissue.

Incorrect Options;

Option A - The extent of a keloid scar can cross the wound margins: Keloid scars are characterized by their tendency to extend beyond the original wound boundaries. Unlike normal scars, which typically stay within the limits of the wound, keloids can grow and spread beyond the initial injury site.

Option B - Wide excision of a keloid scar does not necessarily prevent recurrence: Keloid scars have a high recurrence rate even after surgical removal. While excision may temporarily remove the keloid, it does not guarantee that it won't reappear. Keloids have a complex and poorly understood formation process involving various factors, and surgical removal alone may not address all underlying causes.

Option C - Histopathology of a keloid scar does not typically show reduced collagen and increased vascularity: Keloid scars are characterized by excessive collagen deposition, leading to the formation of raised, firm, and thickened scars. The histopathological examination of keloids typically reveals an abundance of collagen fibers in irregular arrangements. Increased vascularity is not a consistent finding in keloids.

questions.text: What is the most suitable graft for performing a femoropopliteal bypass procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Great saphenous vein:

  • The great saphenous vein, is considered the best graft for a femoropopliteal bypass due to its superior long-term patency rates and overall success in these procedures.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dacron: Dacron, a synthetic graft, is a secondary choice for femoropopliteal bypass due to lower patency rates compared to the great saphenous vein.

Option C - Polytetrafluoroethylene: Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), another synthetic graft, has inferior long-term patency rates to the great saphenous vein for femoropopliteal bypass.

Option D - Short saphenous vein: The short saphenous vein is less favored than the great saphenous vein for femoropopliteal bypass due to its smaller diameter and inferior long-term outcomes.

questions.text: Rodent ulcer is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Basal cell cancer:

  • Rodent ulcer is used to describe basal cell cancer, which is a common type of skin cancer that arises from basal cells in the skin.

  • Rodent ulcer, also referred to as tear cancer, is characterized by local invasiveness, resulting in the destruction of surrounding tissues, typically seen on the face above the line connecting the ear lobule to the angle or corner of the mouth.

  • Emerging from the basal layer of the epidermis, it most frequently occurs on the nose, with inner canthus being another common site.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Squamous cell cancer: Squamous cell cancer, also known as squamous cell carcinoma, is a type of skin cancer that arises from squamous cells. It typically presents as a firm, red nodule or a flat lesion with a scaly or crusty surface. While squamous cell carcinoma is a common type of skin cancer, it is not specifically associated with the term "Rodent ulcer."

Option C - Rhinophyma: Rhinophyma is a condition characterized by the thickening and enlargement of the nose, often resulting in a bulbous or irregular appearance. It is typically associated with severe forms of rosacea and is not related to "Rodent ulcer," which specifically refers to a type of skin cancer.

Option D - Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma is a type of cancer that originates in glandular cells. It can occur in various organs, such as the lung, colon, breast, and prostate. However, it is not associated with the term "Rodent ulcer," which specifically refers to a type of skin cancer.

questions.text: What is the primary concern in managing hand injuries?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Repair to tendons: 

  • Tendons play a crucial role in the movement of the fingers and hand.
  • If there is a significant tendon injury, such as a complete tendon laceration or avulsion, restoring the continuity and function of the tendons becomes a top priority.
  • Tendon repair is important to regain proper hand function and dexterity. In some cases, delayed or inadequate tendon repair can result in long-term impairment of hand movement.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Repair of skin cover: Skin cover refers to the integrity and closure of the skin over the injured area. Skin closure is important to prevent infection, promote wound healing, and provide a protective barrier. Depending on the severity of the hand injury, the need for skin repair or closure may vary. Superficial lacerations or abrasions may require simple wound cleaning and closure, while more complex injuries may necessitate complex wound reconstruction or grafting.

Option C - Repair of nerves: Nerve injuries in the hand can result in sensory loss, motor deficits, and impaired hand function. Nerve repair or reconstruction is crucial in cases of significant nerve injury, such as complete transection or severe compression. The restoration of nerve function can help regain sensation, muscle control, and coordination in the hand. However, the prioritization of nerve repair may depend on the overall severity and complexity of the hand injury.

Option D - All: It is incorrect as tendon repair is the most important factor in the repair of hand injuries.

questions.text: Comment on the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sebaceous cyst: 

  • A sebaceous cyst is a benign, slow-growing, subcutaneous cysts that often appear as smooth, round nodules under the skin.

  • These cysts can occur on the neck and are caused by blocked sebaceous glands.

  • The image shows multiple cyst-like nodules that are consistent with the appearance of sebaceous cysts.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Implantation dermoid: This is a cyst formed by the implantation of epithelial cells into the dermis, typically due to trauma. They are usually solitary, unlike the multiple lesions seen in the image.

Option C - Angular dermoid: A type of dermoid cyst that occurs near the angle of the eye. This option is not consistent with the lesions on the neck.

Option D - Lipoma: Lipomas are benign soft tissue tumors composed of fat. They are typically soft and mobile, but the nodules in the image appear firmer and more consistent with cysts.

questions.text: A plastic surgeon is visited by a 36-year-old African-American male who has a recurring keloid lesion in his left earlobe due to previous injuries. Despite undergoing surgery to remove the lesion, it consistently returns after the procedure. During the examination, the patient has a painless swelling measuring 2 cm in front of his tragus. What is the most suitable approach to manage this recurrent keloid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Intramarginal excision followed by radiation: 

  • Keloids are abnormal scars that result from an exaggerated healing response. They tend to recur after surgical excision.

  • Intramarginal excision, which involves removing the keloid while keeping the wound edges within the boundaries of the original scar, followed by radiation therapy, has shown good results in preventing keloid recurrence.

  • Radiation helps to prevent excessive scar formation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Excisional surgery: Simple excision of the keloid without additional measures is not likely to prevent recurrence, as keloids have a high tendency to come back after surgery.

Option C - Cryosurgery: Cryosurgery involves using extreme cold to destroy abnormal tissue. While it may be useful in some cases, it is generally not considered the primary treatment for recurrent keloids.

Option D - Silicone gel sheeting: Silicone gel sheeting is a non-invasive treatment option that can be used to manage scars, including keloids. However, in the case of a recurrent keloid that has not responded to previous treatments, more aggressive approaches like intramarginal excision and radiation are typically required.
